thread.title: Late sell-off in CBA, ANZ, NAB and Westpac drives ASX losses
thread.title_full: Late sell-off in CBA, ANZ, NAB and Westpac drives ASX losses | afr.com

author: Post to Linkedin
title: Late sell-off in CBA, ANZ, NAB and Westpac drives ASX losses
text:
In a tough day for the banks, CBA fell 5.4 per cent, NAB lost 1.6 per cent and Westpac shed 0.9 per cent. Andrew Quilty Share on twitter by Stephen Cauchi The big banks drove a steep afternoon sell-off on the ASX, overshadowing another busy day of earnings reports including QBE and ANZ.
​ The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index finished 65 points, or 1.2 per cent, lower at 5303.1, while the All Ordinaries index dropped 59 points, or 1.1 per cent, to 5309.4.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia shares traded without the right to a $2.22 dividend and weighed heavily on the sharemarket from the outset, as did energy stocks as global oil prices continued to tumble. By midday, the market had managed to wobble higher with some well-received profit announcements.
However, shares in the big banks began to tumble early in the afternoon, dragging the market down.
The falls have coincided with a warning from ratings agency Fitch that banks are likely to need to raise further capital over the medium term as regulatory changes stemming from the December 2014 financial system inquiry and Basel framework are implemented.
Among the banks, CBA fell 5.4 per cent to $76.91. NAB lost 1.6 per cent to $31.76 and Westpac shed 0.9 per cent to $31.66.
ANZ's trading update showed cash profit in the first nine months of its financial year rose 4 per cent to $5.4 billion, but the stock crumbled 1.9 per cent to $28.97.
The other major market story was US-based Brookfield Infrastructure Partners confirming a binding offer to acquire Asciano for $8.9 billion to create a "global container platform" and an international rail logistics business. Asciano shares shot up 7.1 per cent to $8.69.
 "The main story is Asciano," Sheriden Hure, senior portfolio manager with Aurora Funds Management, said. "It's the middle of reporting season and investors are happy for things to go sideways until a few more reports come out and people work through some of the trends we're seeing.
"It's energy that is the poorest performer today."
Energy stocks sank as Brent crude oil slumped to $US48.62 a barrel. Woodside gave up 1.6 per cent to $32.05, Santos dived 2.3 per cent to $5.84, and Oil Search retraced 2.3 per cent to $6.40.
The release of the Reserve Bank minutes in the afternoon had little impact on market sentiment, she said.
The banks held up until the afternoon and then plummeted and steep falls in Chinese equity markets did not help sentiment.
"It is a bit of a turnaround," CMC Markets chief market analyst Ric Spooner said. "Commonwealth Bank lost its dividend today, so it was weaker as a consequence. I'd put the bank sell-off down to the usual market fluctuations. Presumably, the relatively good start we saw in the morning attracted selling."
Among other blue chip stocks, BHP dropped 0.9 per cent to $24.98, Rio Tinto edged down 0.6 per cent to $50.59 and Telstra gained 0.5 per cent to $6.12.
However, pureplay iron ore miner Fortescue jumped 7.9 per cent to $1.98 on media speculation around the sale of the miner's infrastructure assets.
Among the day's earnings results, QBE Insurance Group added 0.4 per cent to $14.02 after boosting its dividend payout ratio for investors in 2016.
The company said first-half net profit rose 24 per cent to $661 million.
Pathology giant Sonic Healthcare slipped 1.7 per cent to $19.79 after reporting a 5.6 per cent slump in full-year profit to $363.3 million. The weaker profit came despite a 7.3 per cent rise in revenue for the year ended June 30 to $4.2 billion.
Dick Smith crashed 16.5 per cent to $1.67 despite delivering its third consecutive year of sales and earnings growth under new management, reporting a 3.1 per cent increase in underlying net profit to $43.4 million in 2015.
Same-store sales grew just 1 per cent – well below market forecasts – after falling 0.1 per cent in the second half.
Engineering and maintenance group Monadelphous gained 1 per cent to $7.32 despite net profit after tax for the 2015 financial year falling to $105.8 million, down 28 per cent from $146.5 million a year earlier
Challenger leapt 2.5 per cent to $7.08 after posting an 18 per cent rise in assets under management to $60 billion for the year to June, as the annuities giant recorded double-digit growth in earnings.
Sydney Airport gave up 1.2 per cent to $5.63 after announcing it would gain control of the retail operations at the airport's Terminal 3 and move to co-locate domestic and international operations there over the longer term after agreeing on the $535 million purchase of the terminal's lease from Qantas Airways.
The deal was announced as the airport operator reported a better than expected 6.4 per cent rise in half-year EBITDA to $488.3 million.
